Maybe it's known, not sure, but somebody did [[Bloodchief Ascension]] + [[Mindcrank]] to me. Pretty cool actually.
This kind of thing makes me feel even worse for wizards when that SOI pack leak happened.

While I can appreciate the skill and the art, there is always a little sadness when I see alters for the reason you mentioned. Somebody posted a pic of a signed Alpha Lotus on here not too long ago. It was signed by Richard Garfield with a bic pen. While Richard is the man, the writing on an otherwise perfect Lotus just looked terrible.
Yeah, Cryptic Command is a terrible candidate for full art. If the client rarely plays against new players then I guess it doesn't matter much.
Yes, of course. You did your job great. This happens a fair amount with alters, I guess this one struck me specifically because it has a lot of text.
Good job on the alter, I'm just wondering about the client. For a card that has a lot of text, I would think this would be frustrating to play with/against.
Does Tezzeret's Arm count? I think he is the coolest looking Planeswalker.

Also, if you want to get crazy...
[[Sheltering Ancient]]
[[Rhox War Monk]] He doesn't have as much power as others, but he is still bolt proof and lifelink comes in handy, a lot.
He doesn't need legs when he cuts off the opponents' on turn 2.
"In case of severe Eldrazi meta, go home immediately"
At least they aren't rotated 90 degrees.
I don't think it should be seeing play per se, but [[Advent of the Wurm]] is just a good card, not good enough I guess though.
Hm, nope. I genuinely like this more than Twin mirrors, but to each his own.
It might not make sense, but I am enjoying myself, and more so than if Twin was still there.
Even though Twin players may not be happy, I must say, Wizards goal of making a more exciting format to watch has been achieved.

The woman in "What are Little girls made of?" is truly stunning. Great episode too.
The only time when it feels insincere to say GG is when one person was land screwed big time and it truly was NOT a good game at all. A lot of the time GG's are said regardless out of courtesy.
Already banned in Modern.

Since players enjoy making up formats like Commander, Tiny Leaders, and Pauper, why don't they just make an unofficial format that's somewhere between Legacy and Modern. I don't know what this would be, but it's gotta be possible.
Yeah, I suppose for me it's a deeper sadness that I feel like "The Thing" in general is under appreciated - a lot of people either haven't seen it or don't realize how good it is.
I don't mind Randy in particular. I feel that NONE of the ProTour commentators outside of LSV come close to the SCG crew.

I just don't know anymore. It's almost impossible for me to separate nostalgia from artistic preferences, not to mention the gameplay of the cards that we have attachments to. I don't really have any era that I think is bad, but set's that really captured my imagination were Legends and Arabian Nights. Innistrad really nailed a feeling as well.
Never underestimate Lanterns
I am just consistently loving these spoilers.
Can you use it in response to the upkeep trigger when they want to reveal their hand?
I read the cost, the stats, the keywords, and thought "ok, here comes the downside"....._

Oh awesome, thanks! What's crazy is, that wasn't even the music I noticed as Morricone's, so I'm pretty sure there is *another* part in the movie that uses this: https://youtu.be/REYcShr_lQY?list=PL0828E3D6929DFDB6 t=166
I don't remember what is happening in Hateful Eight at that point of the movie, but this is the music is playing. Apparently people in the Youtube comments noticed this as well.
Thank you for the link. I saw a fair amount of these interviews, but I guess I missed this part.

This movie gives a HUGE nod to John Carpenter's "The Thing". The only sad part about this for me is that I think few people will notice this (I could be wrong). The scenario of both movies is putting a bunch of guys indoors, surrounded by a blizzard/extreme cold weather, they start to slowly (or quickly in some cases) distrust each other. On a visual level, it hit me when they have to tie a line to the outhouse. In one scene from H8ful Eight, there is music directly FROM "The Thing" - a score also made by Ennio Morricone. The endings are vaguely similar in that it shows the last 2 guys left and the whole place has gone to shit. But the tone is quite different - the ending of Hateful Eight is pretty much a happy one. Maybe I am just a "Thing" fanboy, but I couldn't help but draw a corollary between the two. And just to be clear, this isn't a "Quentin stole from The Thing!!!" post, it's just something cool I noticed.

Has anybody else been humming the main theme music since seeing the movie? It's been stuck in my head (in a good way). I had been reading and watching interviews of Tarantino talk about his collaboration with Ennio Morricone, so I had high expectations. But the music more than delivered, dare I say it almost eclipsed the movie in a way. As others have mentioned, the opening shot with the crucifix has really stuck with me visually and musically.
[[su-chi]]
* Instant * When target creature dies this turn, put X 1/1 tokens onto the battlefield where X is the creature's toughness.

This part was freakier for me: https://youtu.be/z3nrPbpvhw0?t=38
